instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_R: What is P3V3S5_EN_R? P3V3S5_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP3V3_S5 power rail.  Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Sent my way with problem listed as "not recognizing SSD's" this was dead on arrival.
Found corrosion and rusted pads in the areas between <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. Cleaned it all up, restored pads and replaced several components:
<RESISTOR>R1920</RESISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q1920</TRANSISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R2023</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R1691</RESISTOR>
<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>
<CHIP>U1930</CHIP>
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and
<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>

All I get are the G3H rails and nothing after that, no S4 or up. No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> which if I recall one of Louis' vids is a common issue with the 00165's
Problem is, I can't figure out what creates <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

If I'm reading the schematic right it's <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> but this was replaced and I have continuity everywhere I should have it. I see no EN or ENTRIP pins so not looking for an enable signal. No short to ground either.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No reason to check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> before S5-S3 sleep states are released.
This signal is created from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> via <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR>.

Check voltages at L7520/60; any pulse at least?
Do you get magsafe light at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
L7520 is 0V on both sides, no pulses I can tell of (no oscilloscope available either).
Magsafe light works.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Voltage of <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>?

I'm suspecting a dead <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I messed up in my original post, I did have S5:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
Edited original post to correct that typo that should say "S4"

As for the voltages you asked for:
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_R</SIGNAL> - 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 1.04V
<SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREG3</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
and of course <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V

S4 and up I have 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> should be 3v
​​​​​​its possible that when you first probed the S5 lines were not working because of this

Resistance to ground in Ohms on this line? Any crap around the SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
82.5 kOhm (if I measured that correctly. same as diode mode without the meter on diode mode?)

Was going to give the board another visual inspection so searched BV for all points <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is at.... they now all measure 3.4V ...
Area around SMC is clean.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
82.5kOhm is alright, keep an eye on this voltage though as its one of the first signals we need for the system to do anything.

Voltage of <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
